Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) (a) The regular participants of the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group are the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA), Centrelink, and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Other government agencies, such as the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, attend as required. (b) In March 1997, the ATO, Centrelink, and DIMA formed an Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group to examine opportunities for joint activities. The activities of the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group include: investigating the possibility of undertaking joint prosecutions for taxation and social security offences; outposting Centrelink officers to ATO sites; improving cooperation and information exchange; identifying potential joint activities. (c) Since its establishment in March 1997, the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group has met twelve times. (d) The Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group is an informal working group. It is not a body tasked with recommending to Ministers. Agencies may take ideas and information from the working group and incorporate these into their portfolio responsibilities. The Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group has played an active and critical role in fostering joint activities, extending co-operation and improving the exchange of information between the three agencies. It continues to develop new approaches and monitors the progress of those, which have been put in place. (2) (a) The amount of the maximum penalty of $10,000, which may be imposed on an employer who is convicted of having knowingly employed unlawful non-citizens, has not been reviewed since it became part of migration legislation in September 1994. (b) There is no formula to review that penalty. (3) Since my appointment as Minister, there have been no briefs to the Director of Public Prosecutions in respect of employers who knowingly employ illegal workers. Prosecution of employers who knowingly employ people with no work rights is possible under section 5 of the Crimes Act. Prosecutions, however, have rarely occurred because of: - reluctant supporting witnesses - insufficient evidence to prove "knowingly" or "intent" by employers - the chain of evidence required to meet prosecution standards. (4) I refer the honourable member to my answer of 31 March 1999 on the number of employers who have been convicted of being knowingly concemed with visitors working without permission. (a) The Department has been conducting the Employer Awareness Campaign (EAC) since 1992. The EAC encourages employers to check the work rights of prospective employees and provides them with information on how to do so. The EAC has been a valuable tool used by my Department to help those many responsible employers in Australia who remain committed to ensuring that they employ only Australians and workers with right to work. (b) I have previously indicated my Department's efforts at identifying and acting where people are working without authority. I am concerned, however, that under current law there is no obligation on employers to check the work rights of employees and that it is difficult to establish sufficiently well, for prosecution purposes, that employers may knowingly have recruited people without work rights. The Review of Illegal Workers I have commissioned will consider, among other things, the adequacy of provisions available to discourage employers from recruiting people without the right to work. The review will also e-arnine the adequacy of information available to employers.
